meta.dates: Late September / Early October 2026 (12 days TBD)

travelers.notes: Two married couples in their 50s. Neil & Kim are married; Susie & Brad are married. All experienced travelers looking for relaxed, authentic UK canal experience.

preferences.vibe: Relaxed pace, authentic UK experience. History, real ale pubs, quirky shopping, farm-to-table dining, live music.
preferences.budget: TBD - looking for comfortable but not luxury
preferences.mobility: All in good health, no restrictions
preferences.transportation: NO rental car. Train from London to narrowboat base. Narrowboat for 12 days.
mustHave: Narrowboat with 2 private double cabins (ideally 2 bathrooms for couples' comfort)
Real ale pubs along the route

routing.reasoning: Kim has Delta status and prefers to accumulate miles. ATL has direct Delta flights to London Heathrow (~9 hours). Check alternate Gulf Coast airports for significant savings.

estimatedTotal.notes: Late Sept/early Oct is shoulder season, prices should be reasonable

recommendedCompanies.name: Black Prince - Lower Heyford Base
recommendedCompanies.notes: IDEAL for Oxford Canal. Base is ON the Oxford Canal at Lower Heyford. Direct access to route. Season ends Oct 30, 2026.
recommendedCompanies.trainAccess: Heyford Station is RIGHT NEXT to the base - trains from Oxford (~15 min) or Banbury (~15 min)

recommendedCompanies.name: Black Prince - Napton Base
recommendedCompanies.notes: At junction of Oxford and Grand Union canals. Access to both south to Oxford and north toward Coventry.
recommendedCompanies.trainAccess: Leamington Spa station (~9 miles) - taxi/transfer needed

recommendedCompanies.name: Napton Narrowboats
recommendedCompanies.notes: Family company, high-end boats. 1st Class Fleet has King-Size beds, two bathrooms. 10/11 night holidays available.
recommendedCompanies.recommendedBoat: 1st Class Fleet with reverse layout, two full bathrooms

recommendedCompanies.name: Oxfordshire Narrowboats
recommendedCompanies.notes: Based at Lower Heyford AND Bradford on Avon. 4-8 berth boats with option for 2 en-suite bathrooms.
recommendedCompanies.recommendedBoat: 4-berth 'Stylish and Spacious for Two Couples' boats with two full bathrooms

recommendedCompanies.name: College Cruisers
recommendedCompanies.notes: Based in Oxford. Fleet of 10 narrowboats. Outstanding customer service reputation.
recommendedCompanies.trainAccess: Oxford - direct trains from London Paddington (1 hour)

estimatedCost.notes: Late Sept/early Oct is end of season - good availability, reasonable prices. Premium boats with 2 bathrooms at higher end.

route.description: One of the most beautiful and historic canals in England. Completed in 1790, it's an early contour canal that winds through the landscape rather than cutting through it. Famous for its pretty villages, excellent canalside pubs, and rich history.

stats.typicalWeek: Napton to Oxford and return: ~100 miles, ~45 hours cruising, 78 locks

suggestedItinerary.base: Lower Heyford (Black Prince or Oxfordshire Narrowboats)

option1.name: South to Oxford + North to Banbury
option1.description: 12 days allows both directions from Lower Heyford. South to Oxford (7-8 hours), explore city, then north through Banbury to Cropredy and beyond.

option2.name: Lower Heyford to Napton and back
option2.description: North from Lower Heyford through Banbury, Cropredy, Fenny Compton to Napton Junction (connects to Grand Union). Return same route.

keyStops.name: Oxford
keyStops.pubNote: Many excellent pubs in Jericho area

keyStops.name: Thrupp
highlights: The Jolly Boatman pub (real ales, great food)
keyStops.pubNote: The Jolly Boatman - moor right outside

keyStops.name: Lower Heyford
highlights: Former USAF base at Upper Heyford

keyStops.name: Aynho Wharf
highlights: The Great Western Arms - excellent canalside pub
keyStops.pubNote: Great Western Arms highly recommended - between canal and railway

keyStops.name: Banbury
highlights: Banbury Cross (Victorian replica of medieval original)
Tooley's Historic Boatyard (oldest working dry dock, tours available)
keyStops.moorings: Extensive visitor moorings in town center
keyStops.shopping: Castle Quays, traditional market, antique shops

keyStops.name: Cropredy
highlights: Battle of Cropredy Bridge (1644 Civil War)
pubs: The Red Lion (CAMRA listed, part-thatched, log fires)
The Brasenose Arms (17th century, great food)
keyStops.pubNote: THE star village of the South Oxford Canal. Multiple excellent real ale pubs.

keyStops.name: Fenny Compton
highlights: 'Tunnel Straight' - former tunnel now deep cutting
pubs: The Wharf Inn (leather sofas, beer garden, excellent food)
keyStops.note: Last good supply stop before remote section

keyStops.name: Napton-on-the-Hill
keyStops.distance: Northern limit of South Oxford Canal
highlights: Napton Windmill (visible for hours as canal circles the hill)

keyStops.name: Braunston
keyStops.note: Worth the detour for canal history enthusiasts

history.designer: James Brindley (succeeded by Samuel Simcock and Robert Whitworth)
history.purpose: Bringing coal from Coventry coalfields to Oxford and London via Thames
history.significance: Part of Brindley's grand plan for waterway 'cross' linking Thames, Mersey, Trent and Severn. Was main canal artery to London until Grand Junction Canal opened in 1805.
history.funFact: Last horse-drawn freight narrowboat in Britain (Friendship) operated on Oxford Canal until 1959 - now preserved at National Waterways Museum

oxfordCanalHighlights.name: The Jolly Boatman
oxfordCanalHighlights.notes: Right on canal, real ales, great food. Moor outside.

oxfordCanalHighlights.name: The Bell Inn
oxfordCanalHighlights.notes: Good food and beer on tap. Near base.

oxfordCanalHighlights.name: The Great Western Arms
oxfordCanalHighlights.notes: Between canal and railway. Excellent food, Hook Norton ales. Highly recommended.

oxfordCanalHighlights.name: The Old Auctioneer
oxfordCanalHighlights.notes: Third oldest building in Banbury (1596). Fascinating decor, Savoy Hotel doors.

oxfordCanalHighlights.name: The Red Lion
oxfordCanalHighlights.notes: CAMRA listed. Part-thatched, log fires in winter, 3 changing beers + 2 regular (Butcombe). Few yards from towpath. Garden hosts fringe bands during folk festival.

oxfordCanalHighlights.name: The Brasenose Arms
oxfordCanalHighlights.notes: 17th century. Great food, perfect for lunch or dinner. Rooms available.

oxfordCanalHighlights.name: The Wharf Inn
oxfordCanalHighlights.notes: Traditional canalside. Leather sofas, beer garden, excellent food. Also has hair salon and launderette!

oxfordCanalHighlights.name: Rock of Gibraltar
oxfordCanalHighlights.notes: Named after the Satellite Earth Station nearby

pubs.realAleNote: Many pubs serve Hook Norton ales (local Oxfordshire brewery) and other regional real ales. Look for CAMRA Good Beer Guide listings.

spots.name: Oxford Covered Market
spots.notes: Food, crafts, unique shops. Authentic and quirky.

spots.name: Village antique shops
spots.notes: Many villages have small antique/vintage stores

attractions.name: Tooley's Historic Boatyard
attractions.description: Oldest continuously working dry dock on canal system (since 1790). Tours available showing forge, workshops.
attractions.note: Where canal pioneer Tom Rolt set out in 1930s - his book 'Narrow Boat' led to formation of Inland Waterways Association

attractions.name: Blenheim Palace
attractions.description: UNESCO World Heritage Site. Winston Churchill's birthplace. Capability Brown gardens.

attractions.name: Rousham House & Gardens
attractions.description: Beautifully preserved 18th century gardens with cascades, walled garden, parterre, pigeon house.

attractions.name: Battle of Cropredy Bridge Site
attractions.description: English Civil War battle site (1644). Royalist army under Charles I vs Parliamentary force.

liveMusic.notes: Traditional pub music and folk sessions common in canal pubs. Cropredy is famous for Fairport Convention festival (August) but will have folk music culture year-round.
venues: Check Red Lion and Brasenose Arms in Cropredy
Oxford has many live music venues

photoOps: Napton Windmill from canal (visible for hours)

recommendedRoute.outbound: Heathrow → Paddington (Elizabeth Line, ~30 min) → Oxford (~1 hour) → Heyford Station (~15 min)
recommendedRoute.totalTime: About 2 hours Heathrow to Lower Heyford base
recommendedRoute.notes: Heyford Station is RIGHT NEXT to Black Prince and Oxfordshire Narrowboats bases. Very convenient.

alternative.route: If using Napton base: Heathrow → Paddington → Leamington Spa (via Marylebone or cross to Euston), then taxi (~9 miles)

heathrowConnections.elizabethLine: Heathrow → Paddington in ~30 mins (much cheaper, recommended)

lateSeptEarlyOct.conditions: Beginning of autumn colors, generally mild, some rain possible
lateSeptEarlyOct.daylight: Late Sept: Sunrise ~7am, Sunset ~7pm. Early Oct: ~7:15am / ~6:30pm
lateSeptEarlyOct.clothing: Layers, waterproof jacket, warm fleece, sturdy shoes for lock work

weather.notes: Late September often has good weather - 'Indian summer' possible. Early October still pleasant. Better weather odds than late October.

flights.notes: 4 passengers MOB-LHR round trip, late Sept/early Oct rates

narrowboat.notes: ~£2,400 for 12 days on premium 4-berth with 2 bathrooms

trains.notes: Heathrow to Lower Heyford and return for 4

food.notes: Mix of pub meals, onboard cooking, and special dinners. Budget ~$25-40/person/day

openQuestions: Confirm exact dates (late September vs early October?)
Prefer Lower Heyford base (best train access) or Napton (more route options)?
Get Delta flight quotes from MOB, PNS, GPT, MSY to compare
Any dietary restrictions for pub/restaurant planning?
Interest in Blenheim Palace day trip?
nextSteps: Client to confirm Lower Heyford as preferred base
Contact Black Prince or Oxfordshire Narrowboats for 4-berth/2-bathroom boat availability at Lower Heyford
Book once dates and boat confirmed
